reviewText: While this is cute and I'm looking forward to more shorts like this in VR, I can not recommend this at $5.  It's only a couple of minutes in legth and you are done so you are paying over a $1/minute  If you see it on sale, say 50% or more off, then I would definently say check it out.  There are much better expierences at this price point and below.

reviewText: I'm all for supporting indies, but at 3.99 I'm surprised it took approx 20 people to make this. It's padded out with floating objects which in vr is the norm, and there's literally no story to it. Had high hopes for this - the trailer is basically the 'game'.\n\nIt is beautifully done though, and if it had been longer and more involving probably would have paid a little more for it, too.
voteText: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This VR short film is now free and the screenshots don't really do it justice, since they are really zoomed in on the little guy.  I was quite impressed with the film and it is rather cute.  Hopefully we can get some more claymation-style short films like this one.

The moment 'The Rose and I' started I knew it would be a fine example of a VR short movie, one that I would be happy to show off to others. It immediately felt right, because it takes advantage of the fact that you're in VR. Everything feels so present and three-dimensional. The texturing of the world is well-detailed, not flat and boring. I see interesting things happening where ever I look, and in particular, the main character and surrounding scene is made far more interesting by walking around it, peering into it, looking up close to it, standing farther away. Importantly, it takes place at a scale that viewers are not accustomed to when viewing a short movie, making it far more interesting than some of the other VR short movies that have been released this month, many of which could have just as well been traditional 'flat' experiences.\n\nI haven't even talked about what actually happens in 'The Rose and I', and there's a reason for that. Frankly, I'm not even sure what happened, or if anything really happened at all. At this early stage in the life of VR I'm unconcerned about such things. I was too busy marveling at how novel everything felt -- at how the authors really nailed the feel of a VR movie short -- to actually notice the substance of what happened. That's not a bad thing at all.
Unfortunately it was a little juddery at some parts on the Vive recommended specs, but other than that it was a neat little VR animation.

reviewText: Since they made it free, it's okay. I guess it's like a proof of concept or something for them to test things out and practice.\n\nI recommend this as a preview of things we might get more of in VR. More VR content is always good.

reviewText: Even though this was a very short experience, I enjoyed what I watched. I almost feel like the character was too small to really see well, maybe worked better for the Oculus with it's limited tracking. I was watching on a vive VR headset.

reviewText: Beautiful and charming little story. It's not a game, but just a really nice short VR experience. Great to show off VR to non-gamers. The price is a tad high considering how super short it is, but as long as you're okay with paying the price of 2 coffees for a unique experience then I consider that worth it.

Very well done and creative look at part of \The Little Prince\" done in VR. I really love what they have done with lighting and scale. I also enjoyed being able to get really close to the the little guy on his planet to check out the fine details and animation. You can\'t get that experience anywhere but in VR. Lean way in and walk around a little as this is room scale. Overall a nice short animation demo to show people (it\'s not a game) and a very artistic and well done short that is well worth your time. I would love to see more like this."
